sections.title: About Validating Others
sections.content: Validation means showing someone that their feelings make sense, even if you don't fully agree. It involves listening closely, reflecting what you hear, and acknowledging their emotional experience. Validation builds trust, reduces defensiveness, and helps people feel seen and understood without needing to 'fix' or agree with everything they say.

sections.title: Example
sections.content: After Amit opened up about his painful breakup, Emily didn't rush to fix it or say 'you'll be okay.' She listened and gently said, 'This sounds really painful, and it makes sense you feel devastated. Anyone would hurt after losing someone they care about.' Amit felt understood and safe to keep sharing, knowing she was truly holding space for him.

sections.title: Remember
sections.content: Validation is about connection, not correction. It's holding space for another person's emotions. Slow down, listen fully, validate genuinely, and watch relationships strengthen through understanding.
